reviewText:
I'm surprised no one else reviewed this game. I bought it as part of the 3d Realms anthology. A set of classics that are mostly excellent (though some have already been released like Raptor and Shadow Warrior Classic).

Realm of Chaos had good graphics for a game of its time and was well advanced for a game of its time. A nice smooth scrolling platformer game. The sounds are expected of a game of its time, but the graphics are very nice. The game play is pretty straightforward.

This is definitely a game for nostaglia.

Thanks for re-releasing it!
voteText: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
9/10

I'm not entirely sure, but I think this might be Apogee's best platforming game - and definitely one of their best games overall. The game feels great and works great in everything. It looks good, the soundtrack is good, controls work very well, combat is very fun and the game is quite challenging. The five difficulties grant the game a highly variable challenge level - they don't just change how much health the characters have or how many gems you get, but they also slightly change the layout for some levels. The last difficulty level even adds auto screen scrolling to some levels that normally don't have it, forcing players to be on their toes even on some levels where they'd normally be able to take their time with.

The only things I didn't enjoy too much about this game is that the episode 2 final boss is way too hard in comparison to the rest of the game and the ending is quite lackluster.

An incredibly awesome game, definitely recommended.

reviewText: A hack and slash platformer from one of the masters of classic PC games, Apogee (now 3D Realms). The graphics are great, the music sounds adventurous, and the level design is amazing. Another grand addition for the Apogee Anthology. It would be hard to not recommend this game for retro gamers.

reviewText: Its better than most indy platformers at a fraction of the cost. If you like pixel art, this has got tons of it, plus MIDI music. Whats not to like?

reviewText: You play as a guy with a sword and you can press space to change into a woman that can use range attacks but it requires gems. So you collect gems for the girl and swap between the guy and the girl, depending on whether you need melee or range attacks. This game involves platforming and killing enemies to progress. That's about it.\n\n

reviewText: It's hard to play games that have such little content and repetitive background music and foreground sounds. Sure, the game is from 1995, but even then it didn't get great reviews.\n\nI had absolutely no fun in this game.
